Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Radiate \Ra"di*ate\ (r[=a]"d[i^]*[=a]t), v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Radiated} (r[=a]"d[i^]*[=a]`t[e^]d); p. pr. & vb. n. {Radiating}.] [L. radiatus, p. p. of radiare to furnish with spokes or rays, to radiate, fr. radius ray. See {Radius}, {Ray} a divergent line.] 1. To emit rays; to be radiant; to shine. [1913 Webster]
Virtues shine more clear In them [kings], and radiate like the sun at noon. --Howell. [1913 Webster]
2. To proceed in direct lines from a point or surface; to issue in rays, as light or heat. [1913 Webster]
Light radiates from luminous bodies directly to our eyes. --Locke. [1913 Webster]
radiating adj : diverging from a common point [syn: {radiating(a)}]
